Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2013 07:48PM RobinJoy wrote: I had the same thing happen last year.  There are a few lumps that do not show up on imaging and the only way to know if it's cancer or not is to get a biopsy. My lump was fairly large and growing. My surgeon said a core biopsy could miss some cancer (there could be just a few cells surrounded by scar tissue)and the only way to know for sure if it was or wasn't was to take it out. I don't regret having it removed.  I was lucky it turned out to be b9.  I hope yours is too. good luck with whatever you choose to do.

Posts.Content: May 24, 2014 05:29PM - edited May 24, 2014 05:29PM by RobinJoy Breast cancer at your age is fairly rare. But it's good to get it checked out thoroughly.  It's not something you'd want to gamble with.  Make sure that your doctor orders a sonogram. Mammograms for younger people aren't quite as effective. MRI's are good. But many health plans may not cover it and they yield a lot of false positives.  Good luck and try not to worry. I know easier said than done.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 04:10PM RobinJoy wrote: I hope you can get a biopsy, KGoldman! That's really young for your Grandmother! They really are looking for number of first degree relatives (mother, sisters) with either breast or ovarian cancer.  There's also another fairly rare genetic condition where it relates to high incidences of colon cancer. I wish you all the luck in the world! Keep pushing until you get answers!

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 09:20AM RobinJoy wrote: You sound like me. I've been totally obsessed, too and worried that I might have become a hypochondriac. I notice every little vein. My whole right breast seems like a mass of blue veins. Then at times I convince myself that the lump has gotten smaller. Then at other times it's larger. All to top it off, I got my mammo and sono cd.  I can see the bright white star shaped area near my lump that the radiologist noticed. It looks more menacing everytime I put it on the computer. Nancy's advice really spoke to me. Hang in there and have fun with your kids. It sounds like a good time to go the lake or pool or beach.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2012 09:51PM RobinJoy wrote: Can you get a second opinion? I don't know wether it's cancer or not. But I do know that women your age and younger can have breast cancer.  The odds are much lower. But they're still there.  This isn't said to scare you. But my aunt was 38 years old when she was diagnosed with stage IV bc.  So 35 isn't too young! I would keep pushing until you find out if it's b9 or not. Do you know the ages your relatives were diagnosed at? It they were younger than age 50 you could use that to keep pushing for answers. Good luck!

Posts.Title: A Question About Excisional Biopsies and Sentinel Node Biopsies RobinJoy RobinJoy

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2012 12:51AM RobinJoy wrote: I have white coat syndrome. My blood pressure is usually 112/66. I get to the doctor's office and it's 156/86. So my breast surgeon asked to have my blood pressure under control before I had surgery. The meds made my bp normal during my doctor visits and low otherwise. Well, during my surgery my BP was way too low and they had some trouble waking me.  The point I'm trying to make is make sure your blood pressure doesn't get too low with the meds. And I would like to echo what the other ladies have said. Please consider changing surgeons. It doesn't sound like a good idea to remove your lymph nodes when they may not have any cancer cells.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 12:59AM - edited Aug 22, 2012 01:00AM by RobinJoy Hi Caryn, So sorry you're going through this! Getting the whole lump removed will give them a more complete pathology so you will know exactly what it is.  I know this is very scarey. But it's doable. Better to have it out now and they may not have to do any other surgeries. Sorry to hear about your pup, too. Good luck and know that you're in my prayers!

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2012 01:08PM RobinJoy wrote: It wasn't too bad for me either. Again, the worst part was waiting for the pathology report. I kept an ice pack on mine pretty much all of the time. I'm a major scar former and I didn't want it to stretch and scar more. I also kept a tight sports bra on even at night for a couple of weeks.
Posts.Title: Excisional Biopsy jena FilterLady

Posts.Content: May 29, 2013 12:48PM - edited May 29, 2013 12:54PM by RobinJoy I also have a very strong family history of BC. Every woman on my maternal side has had breast cancer, save for me. Mine grew quickly, had a blood supply and looked very much like it could have been cancerous. When the pathology report came back, it was b9.  My breast surgeon said that if he had to diagnose based on appearances, he would have said it was cancerous. I don't regret having it removed. It's good that your GP is taking it seriously. I think MRI's are a very good idea for someone as young as you. Genetic counseling sounds like another good idea. You're on the right track. Good luck and try not to worry too much. Easier said than done. I know. It sounds like you have a good team on your side and that's the most important thing.
Posts.Title: Mass of normal breast tissue + strong (early) family history? Coralyn RobinJoy

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 11:32AM - edited Aug 1, 2012 11:46AM by RobinJoy That's funny autism_mom, I had an ectopic and the clinic said good news you're pregnant! And it's ok some women bleed through their pregnancies. It was probably endodemtriosis. I had to really complain before they offered to do the test. I lost 5 1/2 pints of blood and if I waited just a few more hours I would not be here to write this. Joanne, I hope you find some answers to what's going on with you. I don't have a clue.  Keep pushing until you get some answers.
Posts.Title: Nipple pain, indentation, and lump - please help and read joanne725 joanne725

Posts.Content: RobinJoy wrote: According to study published in 2003 nearly 4% of those women with cancerous palpable masses received normal or benign findings on both mammography and ultrasonography. Anecdotally, it seems much higher as I've searched through the internet.  This has led me to even more questions.  How many of you diagnosed with BC were told you had dense breasts? Was your bi-rads rating 1, 2 or 3? At what stage were you when you were diagnosed?  What type of tumor was it? And finally, did you have to fight to get an MRI or biopsy or were your doctors supportive?  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: False-Negative Mammogram & Ultrasound Questions RobinJoy RobinJoy

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2012 01:34PM RobinJoy wrote: Thank you ladies :-)  Sommer, yes, I do.
Posts.Title: False-Negative Mammogram & Ultrasound Questions RobinJoy RobinJoy

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2012 05:49PM RobinJoy wrote: I got my pathology report. It was good news. It's B9!!!!!!!!!!! I don't know what's going on with my shoulder. But I'm so happy it's not cancer!!!!!!!!!! My surgeon said that the mass was a mixture of fat and scar tissue.  I'm a major scar former. It made sense and I'm so relieved!!!!!!!!!!! I want to thank all of you amazing women and send blessings and prayers for all of you! You all taught me a lot. And to any women that finds this by searching google for "negative mammograms/ultrasound with a palpable lump", it's still a good thing to have them checked by specialist. The only way to really know the pathology of a mass is to have it biopsied.
